newsitem.title: USA: Cyberonics gets FDA approval for device.
newsitem.headline: Cyberonics gets FDA approval for device.

text.p: Medical device designer Cyberonics Inc said on Wednesday that it received U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval to market its NeuroCybernetic Prosthesis System, which it referred to as the first device treatment option made available for epilepsy.

Also referred to as "a pacemaker for the brain," the implantable device consists of a generator and a nerve stimulator electrode that transmits antiepileptic electrical signals to the brain through the vagus nerve in the neck, the company said in a statement.

"This is the future of epilepsy treatment for hundreds of thousands of people who have not found relief from seizures using existing therapies," said Dr. Douglas Labar of Cornell University's Comprehensive Epilepsy Center.
